attributes.title: Addressing Implicit Bias in Juries
attributes.description: This research intends to learn whether a de-biasing jury instruction is effective at having jurors recognize their own implicit bias and overcome it during deliberation.

q3.value:
This research intends to learn whether a de-biasing jury instruction is effective at having jurors recognize their own implicit bias and overcome it during deliberation.

The majority of the literature points to the existence of juror bias, though there are certainly studies which either do not find effects or who find that there is bias against white defendants. Mitchell et al. (2005), for example, conducted a meta-analysis and found a small but significant effect of racial bias on juror decisions. In another meta-analysis, Sweeney and Haney (1992) found that white mock-jurors give significantly longer sentences to white defendants than to black ones. Archival studies have also found that black defendants have higher conviction rates than white ones, that they tend to receive harsher sentences, and that they are more likely to be sentenced to death. Further, in a mock-juror study, Wuensch et al. (2002) found that jurors favored defendants of their ingroup, particularly when victims were members of an outgroup. In his 2009 dissertation, Lytle also found that individuals display implicit bias against black defendants and that this bias reliably predicts conviction decisions.

However, some studies have found evidence contradicting these findings. In a review of past empirical research, Pfeifer (1990) came to the conclusion that there is little evidence supporting the existence of jurors’ racial bias and that many studies misinterpreted data leading to a false understanding of the state of bias. In another example, Elek and Agor (2014) failed to replicate past findings concerning racial bias and attributed this fact to jurors’ “spontaneous self-correction” in light of society’s recently egalitarian norms. Some have cited this kind of self-correction as a reason for these null effects, particularly in cases where race is salient. Shaw and Skolnick (1995) found in their study that there was an anti-White bias, which deliberation generally eliminated. Another theory suggests that studies which failed to find juror biases bear the mark of social dominance dynamics which obscure the racism at play. 

There have been two empirical studies on the topic of jury instructions aimed at bias reduction, Ingriselli (2014) and Elek and Agor (2014). Outside of these studies, which most directly address the topic at hand, there have been a number of studies concerning jury instructions, more generally. 

Ingriselli (2014)

Ingriselli’s 2014 empirical study considered jury instructions as a potential method of mitigating juror bias and did so within the context of a number of theories on the origins of juror bias. The first theory with which the article contended was aversive racism theory, which holds that juror racism is generally unconscious and is thus driven by implicit biases. It argues that jurors generally want to adhere to their explicitly egalitarian beliefs and suggests, as a consequence, that when race is salient in the process of jury decision-making, jurors will be forced to access their egalitarian beliefs and will self-correct into a state of reduced bias. The other racial bias theory that Ingriselli considered is the social identity theory which claims that, in order to achieve a state of high self-esteem, individuals will seek to elevate their ingroup in comparison to other outgroups. Under this theory, if individuals seek to increase their self-esteem and their circumstances highlight an opportunity to reduce the status of an outgroup member, they will take that opportunity. Finally, the researchers considered the race-neutral theory that any emphasis on procedural justice--that is, the fairness of the justice system—will reduce juror bias by legitimizing the jury decision-making process. 

In order to consider these theories, the study manipulated four independent variables in a 4 (instruction type: egalitarian, self-affirming, procedural, control) x 2 (race salience: high, low) x 2 (instruction timing: pre-evidence, post-evidence) x 3 (racism: non-racist, aversive racist, true racist) between-subjects study. The first variable was the type of instructions which researchers presented to mock jurors. Jurors encountered one of four instruction conditions. First, they could have seen egalitarian instructions (see Appendix A), meant to reduce bias through a form of implicit racial salience suggested by aversive racism theory. Second, they may have encountered self-affirming jury instructions meant to increase their self-esteem as social identity theory suggests. Third, they read a set of instructions highlighting procedural justice. Fourth, in the control condition, they saw only reasonable doubt instructions present in all conditions. The next variable that Ingriselli manipulated was racial salience. In the high racial salience condition participants saw a picture of the black defendant and a bystander in the case description mentioned race; in the low salience condition, participants saw no photo and the bystander merely complained about rising crime rates. Researchers were also interested in considering the timing of jury instructions and so they either presented the instructions before or after the evidence. Finally, the researchers categorized participants into three categories based on their implicit bias (measured through an IAT) and their explicit bias (measured through the Modern Racism Scale). Participants were either non-racists, aversive racists (high implicit, low explicit bias), or true racists. 

Researchers launched the study on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Participants saw a case description and balanced pieces of evidence either before or after jury instructions and the study then asked them to report their verdict (across seven different measures, e.g. level of guilt and recommended sentence). Finally, participants completed the two bias measures. 

The study concluded that non-racists were significantly less biased than true racists and found that black defendants were less likely to be found guilty (according to one measure) if instructions were provided pre-evidence. The study found no support for either social identity theory or an emphasis on procedural justice as effective debiasing tactics. However, there was a three-way interaction between instruction type, instruction timing, and race salience, such that participants gave longer sentences to black defendants when there was low racial salience, when they heard their jury instructions pre-evidence, and when that instruction was egalitarian.  This suggests partial support for aversive racism theory as all the evidence does accord with the theory but it should not have been necessary for all three of these variables to coincide in order to see a reduction in bias. 

It is important to note a number of key shortcomings in the design of this study, however. First, the study was conducted on MTurk online and thus may not be particularly ecologically valid. In addition, the study did not have a white defendant as a control and thus treated increased punitiveness as equivalent to racial bias without evidence that the same trends would not have occurred were the defendant white. Further, in order to categorize participants by their level of bias, research excluded 75 people from their original 412- person sample because they displayed high explicit bias and low implicit bias, which researchers found implausible. In another example of a statistical improbability, half of all participants showed a reverse bias on their IAT such that they scored anti-white. Finally, the researchers found that their study was already “underpowered” and then proceeded to conduct a series of exploratory analyses which removed another sizeable section of their study population.

Elek and Agor (2014)

Elek and Agor (2014) conducted another study concerning the possibility of mitigating juror bias through the use of specialized implicit bias instructions. The study had a 2 (defendant race: black, white) x 2 (victim race: black, white) x 2 (instruction type: specialized, control) factorial design. Researchers conducted the study online, using a representative sample which they obtained through ResearchNow. Participants encountered a two-part study, which researchers presented as two separate studies administered weeks apart. In part one, participants first had to answer jury eligibility questions and then saw a video of a man in judges’ robes presenting one of two sets of instructions. All mock-jurors heard standard pattern instructions on reasonable doubt and assault cases, but those not in the control condition also saw a specialized jury instruction loosely based off the instructions which Judge Mark Bennett has been using in his court (See Appendix for both Bennett’s instructions and Elek and Agor’s instructions). Participants then read one of the case descriptions adapted from Sommers and Ellsworth (2000, 2001) describing an assault case in a college locker room. Researchers manipulated both the race of the defendant (black or white) and the race of the victim (black or white). After the mock-jurors read the facts of the case they answered a number of verdict related questions (e.g. certainty in guilt, sentencing). In part two of the study, participants completed an IAT and a number of explicit bias measures (a measure of warmth toward people of different races, the Symbolic Racism Scale, and the Internal and External Motivation to Respond without Prejudice scales). 
Despite the fact that 86% of their sample displayed an implicit preference for white people, Elek and Agor did not find any evidence of bias in juror decision-making, failing to replicate past studies. They did find that greater IAT bias predicted increased conviction rates, but this did not vary by race. Further, researchers did not find any effects for defendant race. This lack of a baseline level of bias made it difficult for researchers to find whether jury instructions affected bias. The only pattern they found with regard to jury instructions was that the defense case was strongest in the control condition when there was a black victim and a black defendant; this effect was mitigated by specialized bias instructions. The study also did not find that the instructions had any backlash or backfire effects; that is, participants did not display more bias after having heard the instructions.
Researchers explained their failure to replicate largely by hypothesizing that participants engaged in spontaneous self-correction of their biases, given that any minor differences in study design have existed across other studies which have not failed to replicate Sommers and Ellsworth. The study could likely have benefited from a more ecologically valid design as researchers conducted the study on the internet. Further, the population of black mock-jurors was too small to conduct follow up research on their biases. 

This study would be the first RCT to study the effect of de-biasing jury instructions at all and would specifically test it on actual juries, rather than mock juries.

q4.value: If a de-biasing instruction affects implicit bias, then individual juror scores on the IAT will show a reduction in bias from test 1 to test 2 for those that received the instruction as compared to that that did not.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a two-group design.  Jury trials will be randomly assigned to either receive the de-biasing instruction or to not receive the de-biasing instruction.  Jurors serving for a trial will not know that they will or will not receive the instruction.  Jurors serving for a trial will take an IAT before service and after rendering a verdict.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where each trial will be randomly assigned to either receive treatment (a de-biasing jury instruction) or control (no de-biasing jury instruction).  Each juror selected to serve in that trial will not know about the study.  Each juror will take an IAT before service and then after rendering a verdict.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will come from the existing jury pool summoned to serve as jurors on the day in question.  Those selected to serve as jurors in the normal course of business will also become study subjects.  To be a juror, and thus a study subject, participants must be 18 years of age or older.  Subjects will not be paid for participation.

Enrollment will continue for one year beyond launch of the study .

q13.value: Our target sample size is 604 participants.

q14.value: This is the amount of jurors anticipated during a 1 year period.

question.value: We will measure whether administering the de-biasing instruction has the effect of reducing implicit race bias in jurors.  We will then assess whether a reduction in race bias has an effect on trial verdict and jury deliberation time.
We will use regression analysis to analyze our results.

q22.value: We will verify that each subject answered each question in the IAT.  Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the IAT, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect demographic factors of the defendant on trial may be related to juror bias.  Therefore we will look for relationships between race variables and the primary outcome measures of implicit bias.

attributes.title: Parent and Child Predictors of Parental Responsiveness in a Dyadic Free-Play Task

q1.value: Parent and Child Predictors of Parental Responsiveness in a Dyadic Free-Play Task

q2.value: Carly McFall, Leslie Roos, Lauren Kaminski

q3.value:
There appears to be a gap in the literature that addresses which factors have the most substantial impacts on the levels of responsive parenting.  Therefore, the present study will aim to address how parent and child factors have a differential predictive value on parental responsiveness. 

Parental responsivity has implications for the social, cognitive, emotional, and linguistic development of children.  By identifying the factors that affect parental responsiveness, prevention and intervention programs can be designed to target the specific forces that affect responsiveness.  In addition, this research will help provide a better understanding of the factors that affect the responsivity of parents who have children with developmental delays.  This is an important demographic to examine, as children with developmental delays may require enhanced responsiveness from parents to ensure that their needs are being met.  

The present study will be completed through a secondary data analysis, using baseline data collected from the KEEP-P study, which was conducted at the Oregon Social Learning Centre.  The University of Oregon Ethics Board approved the KEEP-P study and the present study. The goal of the KEEP-P study was to encourage the development of positive parenting strategies amongst families caring for children with developmental delays through a 12-week, manualized, evidence-based, group intervention program.  

Research Question: In a sample of children with developmental delays, what are the predictors of responsive parenting, including both parental and child factors?

q4.value: I hypothesize that the combined effect of parental factors will have greater predictive value over parental responsiveness than will child factors.  More specifically, I hypothesize that of the parental factors, those most associated with chronic stress, such as low income, low maternal education, high stress, and high maternal ACEs, will predict lower levels of parental responsiveness (Bailey et al., 2012; Crittenden & Bonvillian, 1984; Crnic et al., 1983; De Falco et al., 2014; Evans et al., 2008; Matheny et al., 1995; Onyskiw et al., 1997; Taylor et al., 2008).  For child factors, I predict that male children, younger children and children regarded as being more difficult will receive higher parental responsivity on average (Diener et al., 2003; Lee, 2013; Vallotton, 2009).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present study is using a single time point design.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data collected for the present study is part of the KEEP Study.  The hypotheses in the present study have not been examined in previous studies.

question.value: Families in Oregon were selected to participate in the KEEP-P program (2014) at the Oregon Social Learning Centre if their children were identified as having developmental delays throughout their participation in the Early Head Start Program.  In addition, families were eligible to participate in this study if their children were between the ages of 30 months to 6 years and were fluent in English.  Children were excluded from this study if they had significant developmental, medical, or physical disorders. Mother-child dyads participated in this study.

q13.value: 227 parent-child dyads participated in this study.

q14.value: The present study is a secondary data analysis, and thus we had limited flexibility in choosing a sample size.

question.value: Not applicable.

The dependent variable in the current study is responsive parenting, which will be measured using the Parenting Interactions with Children: Checklist of Observations Linked to Outcomes (PICCOLO). The PICCOLO is a 29-item questionnaire that examines positive parenting behaviours through parent-child interactions (Roggman, Cook, Innocenti, Jump Norman, & Christiansen, 2009).  This measure can be used to examine parent-child interactions with children ages 10 months to 47 months (Goodlett et al., 2017). The items on the PICCOLO are grouped into four domains, known as responsiveness, encouragement, teaching, and affection.  There are seven items within the responsiveness domain, including items such as, “Pays attention to what child is doing.”  Responsiveness refers to the degree to which parents are aware of their child’s needs and respond accordingly to them.  Next, there are seven items within the encouragement domain, which examines how parents scaffold their child’s attempts at independence, imaginative play, and exploring the world.  Items within this domain include, “Verbally encourages child’s efforts.”  There are eight items within the teaching domain, such as, “Explains reasons for something to child.”  Teaching involves conversing with one’s child, in addition to playing together, providing a cognitively enriching environment, and describing things.  Finally, there are seven items within the affection domain.  One example of this domain includes, “Uses positive expressions with child.”  Affection refers to the positive expression of emotion through words and actions towards one’s child.  The intensity and frequency of parent behaviours are rated on a 3-point scale, with 0 referring to “not at all there,” and 2 referring to “mostly there.”  Interactions between parent and child are recorded for approximately 10 minutes, and then coded by research assistants (Vilaseca et al., 2019b). Researchers have demonstrated that the PICCOLO has good validity and reliability for members of various ethnic groups in the United States.  Studies have also indicated good predictive and construct validity for this measure.  The first PICCOLO was shown to have a .91 Cronbach’s Alpha, .77 interrater reliability, and .78 internal consistency (Roggman, Cook, Innocenti, Norman, & Christiansen, 2013).

Parental stress and adverse childhood experiences will be the parental independent variables examined in the present study.  Parental stress will be measured using the Parenting Stress Index: Short Form. The Parenting Stress Index: Short Form (PSI: SF) is a measure designed to assess the level of stress experienced by individuals as a result of parenting (Lee, Gopalan, & Harrington, 2016).  This measure was developed in 1995 by Abidin and is used for parents with children under the age of 12.  The PSI: SF is composed of 36 items, which are equally divided into three subscales, known as Parental Distress, Difficult Child, and Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction.  The Parental Distress subscale, which includes items such as, “There are quite a few things that bother me about my life,” measures the distress individuals feel in their parenting role, in addition to how parental responsibilities may be limiting their opportunities.  The degree to which a child’s abilities and temperament frustrate a parent is examined by the Difficult Child subscale, which includes items like, “It takes a long time and it is very hard for this child to get used to new things.”  The Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction subscale, which includes items such as, “This child reacts very strongly when something happens that he/she doesn’t like,” examines the parent’s perception of negative child reactions during interactions with one another.  Of the 36 items on the PSF: SF, 33 items are scored on a 5-point scale, with 1 referring to “strongly agree,” and 5 referring to “strongly disagree.”  Three of the items on the PSI: SF have different response options for the 5-point Likert scale.  Item 22 has response options, from 1 to 5, of “not very good at being a parent,” “a person who has some trouble being a parent,” “an average parent,” “a better than average parent,” and “a very good parent.”  Item 32 has response options, from 1 to 5, as “much harder than expected,” “somewhat harder than expected,” “about as hard as expected,” “somewhat easier than expected,” and “much easier than expected.”  Item 33 has response options, from 1 to 5, as “10+,” “8–9,” “6–7,” “4–5,” and “1–3.”  A total score may be obtained by adding up the three subscale scores.  Lower parental stress is indicated by a lower total score.  Internal reliability consistency, as indicated by Cronbach’s alpha, was determined to be .91 for the PSI: SF (Abidin, 1995).  In addition, Abidin found the Cronbach’s alpha to be .80 for the Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction subscale, .85 for the Difficult Child subscale, and .87 for the Parental Distress subscale.

Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are another parental independent variable to be examined in this study. ACEs will be measured using the ACEs Questionnaire. The Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) Questionnaire assesses the degree to which individuals were exposed to ACEs from birth to the age of 18 (Dube et al., 2003).  There are three variables examined in the ACE Questionnaire, including abuse, neglect, and household dysfunction.  The abuse variables included physical abuse, psychological abuse, and contact sexual abuse.  Questions were modified from the Conflict Tactics Scale (CTS) to create the physical psychological abuse categories (Strauss, 1979).  Participants respond to questions modified from the CTS by selecting, “never,” “once or twice,” “sometimes,” “often,” or “very often.”  For psychological abuse, responses of “often” or “very often” are considered as exposure to emotional abuse (Dube et al., 2003).  Exposure to physical abuse is defined by responses of “sometimes,” “often,” or “very often.”  An example of a question from this category includes, “Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often hit you so hard that you had marks or were injured?” (Felitti et al., 1998).  Psychological abuse is defined by two questions, such as “Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often swear at, insult, or put you down?” (Felitti et al., 1998).  Four questions from Wyatt (1985) were modified to create the contact sexual abuse category, such as, “Did an adult or person at least 5 years older ever have you touch their body in a sexual way?” (Felitti et al., 1998).  Participants may answer “yes” or “no” to any of the four questions from Wyatt.  Selecting the response “yes” is coded as exposure to contact sexual abuse.  Neglect variables include physical and emotional neglect.  Researchers modified items from the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ) (Bernstein et al., 1994) to develop items for the neglect variables.  Participants respond using a 5-point Likert scale, with 1 representing “never true” and 5 representing “very often true.”  Items are reverse scored if need be.  Physical neglect includes five questions, such as “I didn't have enough to eat.”  Two questions are reverse scored in this category.  Scores from these five questions are added together to reveal a total score.  Exposure to physical neglect is defined by a score of 10 or more.  Emotional neglect includes five questions, such as “There was someone in my family who helped me feel important or special.”  After reverse scoring all five questions, scores are added together.  Exposure to emotional neglect is defined by a score of 15 or more.  The household dysfunction variables include four categories, such as violence against the mother, criminal behaviour in the household, substance abuse, and mental illness.  The category of violence against the mother was developed using four questions from the CTS (Strauss, 1979).  Violence against the mother is defined by a response of “sometimes,” “often,” or “very often” to the first two questions, or if the participant selected any other response than “never” to the last two questions.  One example of a question includes, “Was your mother (or stepmother) ever repeatedly hit over at least a few minutes?”  Next, exposure to criminal behaviour in the household is defined by answering “yes” to the question, “Did a household member go to prison?”  Participants are considered as having experienced exposure to substance abuse if they answer “yes” to either of the two questions asked in this category, such as, “Live with anyone who used street drugs?” (Schoenborn, 1991).  Exposure to mental illness is indicated by answering “yes” to either of the two questions in this category, including, “Was a household member depressed or mentally ill?” Dube, Williamson, Thompson, Felitti, and Anda (2004) found the test-retest reliability kappa coefficients range from .56 to .72 for domestic violence, and physical and psychological abuse for the ACEs Questionnaire, and from .46 to .86 for items with dichotomous response options. 

Child behaviour will be the child independent variable examined in the present study.  Child behaviour will be examined through the Child Behaviour Checklist and the Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional. The Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional (ASQ: SE) assesses the parent’s perceptions of their child’s social and emotional development (Squires, Bricker, & Twombly, 2002).  This questionnaire includes items relevant to emotional and social development, including communication, autonomy, interactions with people, compliance, self-regulation, affect, and adaptive behaviour.  Five versions of this questionnaire were used in this study, with each version corresponding to a particular age range, including 21-26 months, 27-32 months, 33-41 months, 42-53 months, and 54-65 months.  Parents filled out the version that corresponded to their child’s age.  The number of items increases with each version of the questionnaire, with the 21-26-month questionnaire having 29 items, and the 54-65-month questionnaire having 36 items.  Most items on the ASQ: SE are scored using a 3-point scale, with 1 referring to “most of the time,” and 3 referring to “rarely or never.”  In addition, parents are asked to circle whether each of these 25 items is a concern (1) or not a concern (2).  Three questions ask parents to provide open-ended written responses.  One question is both a Likert-scale question and an open-ended free response question.  After questionnaires are completed, scores are converted to denominations of 0, 5, and 10.  Child social and emotional problems are indicated by high scores on this measure (Heo & Squires, 2012).  The internal consistency was found to be at an alpha of .82 in a study by Squires, Bricker, Heo, and Twombly (2001) assessing the ASQ: SE.  In addition, the test-retest reliability was found to be .94, while specificity ranged from .82 to .96, and sensitivity was found as a range from .75 to .89.

The Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL) was also used to assess child behaviour.  The CBCL asks parents to describe their child’s behavioural and emotional problems on a 103-item questionnaire (Achenbach, 1992).  Of these items, 99 items are Likert style questions in which parents are asked to think about whether the item either currently, or within the past two months, reflects their child’s behaviours.  Parents respond by circling one of three response options, with 2 representing “very true or often true” and 0 reflecting “not true” of the child’s behaviour.  Four additional items ask parents to respond by writing about their children.  There are five scales in the CBCL that correspond to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), including Pervasive Developmental Problems, Anxiety Problems, Affective Problems, Oppositional Defiant Problems, and Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Problems.  An additional seven Syndrome scales are included in the CBCL, which include Anxious/Depressed, Sleep Problems, Emotionally Reactive, Aggressive Behavior, Withdrawn, Somatic Complaints, and Attention Problems.  A Total Problems score is calculated from the scales, in addition to scores reflecting Externalizing Problems and Internalizing Problems.  Myers (2013) found coefficient alpha reliabilities that were calculated for the DSM scales (.63 to .86), the Syndrome scales (.66 to .92), and the Total Problems score (.95).  Researchers also calculated test-rest reliability for these three scores, which indicated that values of .74 to .87 for the DSM scales, .68 to .92 for the Syndrome scales, and .85 for the Total Problems score.  

Sociodemographic co-variates will include child age, household income, and child gender. Sociodemographic factors will be examined through the Caregiver Demographic Questionnaire.

I will be using the total responsiveness domain score from the PICCOLO to reflect the dependent variable of responsive parenting.  I will be using total scores from the domains of abuse variables, neglect variables, and household dysfunction variables in order to examine the Adverse Childhood Experiences.  To examine parent stress, I will be using total scores from the Parental Distress, Difficult Child, and Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction subscales on the Parent Stress Index: Short Form.  To examine child behaviour, total scores from the subscales on the Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional will be used.  In addition, total problems scores, externalizing, and internalizing scores will be used from the Child Behaviour Checklist to examine child behaviour.

A stepwise regression will be used in the present study.  Responsive parenting is the outcome variable in this study.  Parental stress, adverse childhood experiences, and child behaviour are the predictor variables.  Sociodemographic co-variates will include child age, household income, and child gender. 

Stepwise regression analysis is used to determine the group of predictor variables that best explain the outcome variable.

q21.value: We will use p < .05 in the present study analysis for the p value threshold and use 95% confidence intervals.

q22.value: No outliers are expected because these measures are largely standardized.  However, anything larger than 3 SDs away from mean will be winsorized. Winsorizing is a strategy that can be used to minimize the effects of outliers on data. This process involves taking the outlier values and replacing them with the maximum values at threshold. In this study, any values larger than 3 SDs away from the mean will be removed and replaced.

q23.value: Any missing data points will be excluded because it is expected that there will be less than 15% missing on any given measure.

q24.value: Based on moderation, we might look at the simple effects of child behavior on parent responsiveness at different levels of parent stress.

registration_responses.q1: Parent and Child Predictors of Parental Responsiveness in a Dyadic Free-Play Task
registration_responses.q2: Carly McFall, Leslie Roos, Lauren Kaminski
registration_responses.q3:
There appears to be a gap in the literature that addresses which factors have the most substantial impacts on the levels of responsive parenting.  Therefore, the present study will aim to address how parent and child factors have a differential predictive value on parental responsiveness. 

Parental responsivity has implications for the social, cognitive, emotional, and linguistic development of children.  By identifying the factors that affect parental responsiveness, prevention and intervention programs can be designed to target the specific forces that affect responsiveness.  In addition, this research will help provide a better understanding of the factors that affect the responsivity of parents who have children with developmental delays.  This is an important demographic to examine, as children with developmental delays may require enhanced responsiveness from parents to ensure that their needs are being met.  

The present study will be completed through a secondary data analysis, using baseline data collected from the KEEP-P study, which was conducted at the Oregon Social Learning Centre.  The University of Oregon Ethics Board approved the KEEP-P study and the present study. The goal of the KEEP-P study was to encourage the development of positive parenting strategies amongst families caring for children with developmental delays through a 12-week, manualized, evidence-based, group intervention program.  

Research Question: In a sample of children with developmental delays, what are the predictors of responsive parenting, including both parental and child factors?
registration_responses.q4: I hypothesize that the combined effect of parental factors will have greater predictive value over parental responsiveness than will child factors.  More specifically, I hypothesize that of the parental factors, those most associated with chronic stress, such as low income, low maternal education, high stress, and high maternal ACEs, will predict lower levels of parental responsiveness (Bailey et al., 2012; Crittenden & Bonvillian, 1984; Crnic et al., 1983; De Falco et al., 2014; Evans et al., 2008; Matheny et al., 1995; Onyskiw et al., 1997; Taylor et al., 2008).  For child factors, I predict that male children, younger children and children regarded as being more difficult will receive higher parental responsivity on average (Diener et al., 2003; Lee, 2013; Vallotton, 2009).

registration_responses.q8.question: The present study is using a single time point design.
registration_responses.q12.question: Families in Oregon were selected to participate in the KEEP-P program (2014) at the Oregon Social Learning Centre if their children were identified as having developmental delays throughout their participation in the Early Head Start Program.  In addition, families were eligible to participate in this study if their children were between the ages of 30 months to 6 years and were fluent in English.  Children were excluded from this study if they had significant developmental, medical, or physical disorders. Mother-child dyads participated in this study.
registration_responses.q16.question: Not applicable.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The dependent variable in the current study is responsive parenting, which will be measured using the Parenting Interactions with Children: Checklist of Observations Linked to Outcomes (PICCOLO). The PICCOLO is a 29-item questionnaire that examines positive parenting behaviours through parent-child interactions (Roggman, Cook, Innocenti, Jump Norman, & Christiansen, 2009).  This measure can be used to examine parent-child interactions with children ages 10 months to 47 months (Goodlett et al., 2017). The items on the PICCOLO are grouped into four domains, known as responsiveness, encouragement, teaching, and affection.  There are seven items within the responsiveness domain, including items such as, “Pays attention to what child is doing.”  Responsiveness refers to the degree to which parents are aware of their child’s needs and respond accordingly to them.  Next, there are seven items within the encouragement domain, which examines how parents scaffold their child’s attempts at independence, imaginative play, and exploring the world.  Items within this domain include, “Verbally encourages child’s efforts.”  There are eight items within the teaching domain, such as, “Explains reasons for something to child.”  Teaching involves conversing with one’s child, in addition to playing together, providing a cognitively enriching environment, and describing things.  Finally, there are seven items within the affection domain.  One example of this domain includes, “Uses positive expressions with child.”  Affection refers to the positive expression of emotion through words and actions towards one’s child.  The intensity and frequency of parent behaviours are rated on a 3-point scale, with 0 referring to “not at all there,” and 2 referring to “mostly there.”  Interactions between parent and child are recorded for approximately 10 minutes, and then coded by research assistants (Vilaseca et al., 2019b). Researchers have demonstrated that the PICCOLO has good validity and reliability for members of various ethnic groups in the United States.  Studies have also indicated good predictive and construct validity for this measure.  The first PICCOLO was shown to have a .91 Cronbach’s Alpha, .77 interrater reliability, and .78 internal consistency (Roggman, Cook, Innocenti, Norman, & Christiansen, 2013).

Parental stress and adverse childhood experiences will be the parental independent variables examined in the present study.  Parental stress will be measured using the Parenting Stress Index: Short Form. The Parenting Stress Index: Short Form (PSI: SF) is a measure designed to assess the level of stress experienced by individuals as a result of parenting (Lee, Gopalan, & Harrington, 2016).  This measure was developed in 1995 by Abidin and is used for parents with children under the age of 12.  The PSI: SF is composed of 36 items, which are equally divided into three subscales, known as Parental Distress, Difficult Child, and Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction.  The Parental Distress subscale, which includes items such as, “There are quite a few things that bother me about my life,” measures the distress individuals feel in their parenting role, in addition to how parental responsibilities may be limiting their opportunities.  The degree to which a child’s abilities and temperament frustrate a parent is examined by the Difficult Child subscale, which includes items like, “It takes a long time and it is very hard for this child to get used to new things.”  The Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction subscale, which includes items such as, “This child reacts very strongly when something happens that he/she doesn’t like,” examines the parent’s perception of negative child reactions during interactions with one another.  Of the 36 items on the PSF: SF, 33 items are scored on a 5-point scale, with 1 referring to “strongly agree,” and 5 referring to “strongly disagree.”  Three of the items on the PSI: SF have different response options for the 5-point Likert scale.  Item 22 has response options, from 1 to 5, of “not very good at being a parent,” “a person who has some trouble being a parent,” “an average parent,” “a better than average parent,” and “a very good parent.”  Item 32 has response options, from 1 to 5, as “much harder than expected,” “somewhat harder than expected,” “about as hard as expected,” “somewhat easier than expected,” and “much easier than expected.”  Item 33 has response options, from 1 to 5, as “10+,” “8–9,” “6–7,” “4–5,” and “1–3.”  A total score may be obtained by adding up the three subscale scores.  Lower parental stress is indicated by a lower total score.  Internal reliability consistency, as indicated by Cronbach’s alpha, was determined to be .91 for the PSI: SF (Abidin, 1995).  In addition, Abidin found the Cronbach’s alpha to be .80 for the Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction subscale, .85 for the Difficult Child subscale, and .87 for the Parental Distress subscale.

Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are another parental independent variable to be examined in this study. ACEs will be measured using the ACEs Questionnaire. The Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) Questionnaire assesses the degree to which individuals were exposed to ACEs from birth to the age of 18 (Dube et al., 2003).  There are three variables examined in the ACE Questionnaire, including abuse, neglect, and household dysfunction.  The abuse variables included physical abuse, psychological abuse, and contact sexual abuse.  Questions were modified from the Conflict Tactics Scale (CTS) to create the physical psychological abuse categories (Strauss, 1979).  Participants respond to questions modified from the CTS by selecting, “never,” “once or twice,” “sometimes,” “often,” or “very often.”  For psychological abuse, responses of “often” or “very often” are considered as exposure to emotional abuse (Dube et al., 2003).  Exposure to physical abuse is defined by responses of “sometimes,” “often,” or “very often.”  An example of a question from this category includes, “Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often hit you so hard that you had marks or were injured?” (Felitti et al., 1998).  Psychological abuse is defined by two questions, such as “Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often swear at, insult, or put you down?” (Felitti et al., 1998).  Four questions from Wyatt (1985) were modified to create the contact sexual abuse category, such as, “Did an adult or person at least 5 years older ever have you touch their body in a sexual way?” (Felitti et al., 1998).  Participants may answer “yes” or “no” to any of the four questions from Wyatt.  Selecting the response “yes” is coded as exposure to contact sexual abuse.  Neglect variables include physical and emotional neglect.  Researchers modified items from the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ) (Bernstein et al., 1994) to develop items for the neglect variables.  Participants respond using a 5-point Likert scale, with 1 representing “never true” and 5 representing “very often true.”  Items are reverse scored if need be.  Physical neglect includes five questions, such as “I didn't have enough to eat.”  Two questions are reverse scored in this category.  Scores from these five questions are added together to reveal a total score.  Exposure to physical neglect is defined by a score of 10 or more.  Emotional neglect includes five questions, such as “There was someone in my family who helped me feel important or special.”  After reverse scoring all five questions, scores are added together.  Exposure to emotional neglect is defined by a score of 15 or more.  The household dysfunction variables include four categories, such as violence against the mother, criminal behaviour in the household, substance abuse, and mental illness.  The category of violence against the mother was developed using four questions from the CTS (Strauss, 1979).  Violence against the mother is defined by a response of “sometimes,” “often,” or “very often” to the first two questions, or if the participant selected any other response than “never” to the last two questions.  One example of a question includes, “Was your mother (or stepmother) ever repeatedly hit over at least a few minutes?”  Next, exposure to criminal behaviour in the household is defined by answering “yes” to the question, “Did a household member go to prison?”  Participants are considered as having experienced exposure to substance abuse if they answer “yes” to either of the two questions asked in this category, such as, “Live with anyone who used street drugs?” (Schoenborn, 1991).  Exposure to mental illness is indicated by answering “yes” to either of the two questions in this category, including, “Was a household member depressed or mentally ill?” Dube, Williamson, Thompson, Felitti, and Anda (2004) found the test-retest reliability kappa coefficients range from .56 to .72 for domestic violence, and physical and psychological abuse for the ACEs Questionnaire, and from .46 to .86 for items with dichotomous response options. 

Child behaviour will be the child independent variable examined in the present study.  Child behaviour will be examined through the Child Behaviour Checklist and the Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional. The Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional (ASQ: SE) assesses the parent’s perceptions of their child’s social and emotional development (Squires, Bricker, & Twombly, 2002).  This questionnaire includes items relevant to emotional and social development, including communication, autonomy, interactions with people, compliance, self-regulation, affect, and adaptive behaviour.  Five versions of this questionnaire were used in this study, with each version corresponding to a particular age range, including 21-26 months, 27-32 months, 33-41 months, 42-53 months, and 54-65 months.  Parents filled out the version that corresponded to their child’s age.  The number of items increases with each version of the questionnaire, with the 21-26-month questionnaire having 29 items, and the 54-65-month questionnaire having 36 items.  Most items on the ASQ: SE are scored using a 3-point scale, with 1 referring to “most of the time,” and 3 referring to “rarely or never.”  In addition, parents are asked to circle whether each of these 25 items is a concern (1) or not a concern (2).  Three questions ask parents to provide open-ended written responses.  One question is both a Likert-scale question and an open-ended free response question.  After questionnaires are completed, scores are converted to denominations of 0, 5, and 10.  Child social and emotional problems are indicated by high scores on this measure (Heo & Squires, 2012).  The internal consistency was found to be at an alpha of .82 in a study by Squires, Bricker, Heo, and Twombly (2001) assessing the ASQ: SE.  In addition, the test-retest reliability was found to be .94, while specificity ranged from .82 to .96, and sensitivity was found as a range from .75 to .89.

The Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL) was also used to assess child behaviour.  The CBCL asks parents to describe their child’s behavioural and emotional problems on a 103-item questionnaire (Achenbach, 1992).  Of these items, 99 items are Likert style questions in which parents are asked to think about whether the item either currently, or within the past two months, reflects their child’s behaviours.  Parents respond by circling one of three response options, with 2 representing “very true or often true” and 0 reflecting “not true” of the child’s behaviour.  Four additional items ask parents to respond by writing about their children.  There are five scales in the CBCL that correspond to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), including Pervasive Developmental Problems, Anxiety Problems, Affective Problems, Oppositional Defiant Problems, and Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Problems.  An additional seven Syndrome scales are included in the CBCL, which include Anxious/Depressed, Sleep Problems, Emotionally Reactive, Aggressive Behavior, Withdrawn, Somatic Complaints, and Attention Problems.  A Total Problems score is calculated from the scales, in addition to scores reflecting Externalizing Problems and Internalizing Problems.  Myers (2013) found coefficient alpha reliabilities that were calculated for the DSM scales (.63 to .86), the Syndrome scales (.66 to .92), and the Total Problems score (.95).  Researchers also calculated test-rest reliability for these three scores, which indicated that values of .74 to .87 for the DSM scales, .68 to .92 for the Syndrome scales, and .85 for the Total Problems score.  

Sociodemographic co-variates will include child age, household income, and child gender. Sociodemographic factors will be examined through the Caregiver Demographic Questionnaire.
registration_responses.q18.question: I will be using the total responsiveness domain score from the PICCOLO to reflect the dependent variable of responsive parenting.  I will be using total scores from the domains of abuse variables, neglect variables, and household dysfunction variables in order to examine the Adverse Childhood Experiences.  To examine parent stress, I will be using total scores from the Parental Distress, Difficult Child, and Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction subscales on the Parent Stress Index: Short Form.  To examine child behaviour, total scores from the subscales on the Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional will be used.  In addition, total problems scores, externalizing, and internalizing scores will be used from the Child Behaviour Checklist to examine child behaviour.
registration_responses.q19.question:
A stepwise regression will be used in the present study.  Responsive parenting is the outcome variable in this study.  Parental stress, adverse childhood experiences, and child behaviour are the predictor variables.  Sociodemographic co-variates will include child age, household income, and child gender. 

Stepwise regression analysis is used to determine the group of predictor variables that best explain the outcome variable.

attributes.title: Reducing Partisan Affective Polarization through Common Humanity and Perspective-Taking: an online survey experiment in the United States

q1.value: Reducing Partisan Affective Polarization through Common Humanity and Perspective-Taking: an online survey experiment in the United States

q2.value: Gábor Simonovits, Levente Littvay, Jennifer McCoy

q3.value:
Background
This paper employs a large online survey experiment in the United States to test social psychology mechanisms of reducing partisan affective polarization that harms democracy (Iyengar et al., 2012; McCoy, Rahman, Somer 2018). This experiment employs two mechanisms previously identified in social psychology to reduce out-group bias to determine if they also reduce the out-party dislike and stereotyping characteristic of partisan affective polarization:  stimulating a sense of common humanity as a superordinate identity (e.g. Motyl et al., 2011), and stimulating perspective-taking (e.g. Simonovits et al., 2018). 
Both of these approaches have been shown to reduce intergroup prejudice in other settings and thus the goal of this project is to test whether they could be successfully deployed in the context of affective polarization. After a series of pilot experiments in which we developed and tested various stimuli suggested by previous research to trigger feelings of perspective taking and shared humanity with an outgroup we now set out to test the following hypotheses in a large experiment:

q4.value:
1. Recategorization to identify with common humanity through helping behavior reduces out-group antipathy and threat, relative to the control group.

2. Generating a sense of empathy through perspective-taking reduces out-group antipathy and threat, relative to the control group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study employs a between-subjects design in which treated participants are asked to write a series of short essays about a fictional person described in a vignette. In the Perspective-taking condition, the vignette describes a person (whose gender is matched to the respondent) who had a traumatic experience that led them to completely change their political views and as a result was ostracized by their friends. Respondents are asked to think and elaborate in writing how they would feel in this situation, and could they imagine an experience that would change their own political perspective. In the shared humanity condition, the vignette describes a coworker who supports the out-party and whose three-year old child was  just diagnosed with a life-threatening illness. Respondents are asked to think and elaborate in writing how would they react in this situation. In the control condition subjects are asked to recall and elaborate on the main activities they engaged in day before. 
We estimate the effect of these stimuli on affective polarization by comparing the responses of subjects to a battery of questions measuring political polarization - that is, beliefs and feelings towards the in and out-party -  across those in the treated groups and the control group.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We field our survey through Lucid, the largest US marketplace for online panels. Participants sign up to become members of panels with Providers. These Providers contract with Lucid, who directs participants to purchasers (typically market research firms, but here us, the researchers). Participants are reimbursed by the Providers, typically with money or reward points.

q13.value: We will field the experiment to a sample of 3,000 subjects in the context of a multi-investigator project.

q14.value: Lucid charges $1/subject and sets a maximum survey length. Thus, the size of the study was determined by the resource constraints of the collaborative team.

question.value: The study employs a between-subjects design in which treated participants are asked to write a series of short essays about a fictional person described in a vignette. In the Perspective-taking condition, the vignette describes a person (whose gender is matched to the respondent) who had a traumatic experience that led them to completely change their political views and as a result was ostracized by their friends. Respondents are asked to think and elaborate in writing how they would feel in this situation, and could they imagine an experience that would change their own political perspective. In the shared humanity condition, the vignette describes a coworker who supports the out-party and whose three-year old child was  just diagnosed with a life-threatening illness. Respondents are asked to think and elaborate in writing how would they react in this situation. In the control condition subjects are asked to recall and elaborate on the main activities they engaged in day before.

Pre-treatment variables

Because we are interested in the relative attitudes of our subjects towards individuals belonging to their in-party and out-party, we first elicit their partisan identification using the standard ANES 5 points scale.. In order to minimize the number of subjects who do not choose a preferred party - and thus would be dropped from our analyses --  we terminate the survey for pure independents. 

We classify each respondents to Democrat or Republican based on this set of items - with classifying learners as supporting the respective party. In some of our subsequent survey questions we use this variable to “pipe” in the subjects in-party vs. out-party (e.g. if a respondent chooses Democrat, we will only ask them about their social distance from Republicans and their strength of identification with Democrats).

We also measure subjects’ partisan identity strength using a series of 4 questions developed by Huddy, Mason and Aaroe (2015). 


How well does the term Democrat/Republican describe you? (Extremely well - Not well at all)
How important is being a Democrat/Republican to you? (Extremely important - not at all important)
When talking about Democrat/Republican, how often do you use "we" instead of "they"? (Never - All the time)
How much do you have a lot in common with other ${e://Field/respondent_party}s. (Not at all-Great deal)

We combine these responses - all measured on a 5 point scale - to come up with a continuous measure of identity strength. Given that we have found during our pilots that this variable is highly predictive of our outcome of interest we use this variable as a covariate in our statistical analysis as well as a moderator.

Dependent measures

Feeling thermometers

We first measure general affect towards individuals and groups. In particular, we ask “How do you feel about these groups and individuals?” and present subject with a series of sliders on which they are asked to rate

Donald Trump
Bernie Sanders
Trump supporters
Trump opposers
Bernie supporters
Bernie opposers
Republican politicians
Democrat Politicians
Republican voters
Democrat voters

Each of these targets are rated on a 100-point scale with values not shown but choices labeled with “Extremely negative”, “Neither positive nor negative” and “Extremely positive”.

For our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between pairs of responses (e.g. |Republican voters - Democrat voters|), (2) averaging these absolute differences across pairs and (3) re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.
Traits

We next measure stereotypes that respondents might have about the voters of the two parties.  In particular, we ask “For each item, please indicate how well you think it applies to people who vote for the Democratic Party/Republican Party” and present subject with a matrix in which they rate the two targets on the following traits:
Patriotic
Intelligent
Open minded
Hypocritical
Selfish
Mean

For each trait, we provide 5 response options that range from “Not well at all” to “Extremely well”. We present each subject with this series of items for both parties in randomized order.

Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between pairs of responses (e.g. |Republicans are mean- Democrats are mean|), (2) averaging these absolute differences across pairs and (3) re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.

Emotions

We next measure the extent to which voters of the two parties trigger different emotions form subjects. In particular, we ask “To what extent do Democratic/Republican voters make you feel...” (
Disgusted
Angry
Afraid
Hopeful
Enthusiastic
Proud

For each trait, we provide 5 response options that range from “Not at all” to “A great deal”. We present each subject with this series of items for both parties in randomized order.

Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between pairs of responses (e.g. |Republicans are mean- Democrats are mean|), (2) averaging these absolute differences across pairs and (3) re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.

Trust

We next measure the extent to which subjects trust voters of the two parties. In particular, we ask “To what extent do you think you can trust Republican/Democratic Party voters to do what is right for the country?” 

We provide 5 response options that range from “Not at all” to “To a great deal.  Again, we ask about both parties in randomized order). 

Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between the two responses and re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.

Social distance

Finally, we ask a series of 5 questions measuring social distance form the outparty. The questions are as follows:

How comfortable would you feel dating someone from a different political perspective (if you were single)?
How comfortable are you doing business with a supporter of the Democrats/Republicans?
Suppose a son or daughter of yours was getting married. How would you feel if he or she married a supporter of the Democrats/Republicans?
How comfortable are you having neighbors on your street who are Democrats/Republicans?
How comfortable are you having close personal friends who are Democrats/Republicans? 

For each item, we provide 5 response options that range from “Extremely comfortable” to “Extremely uncomfortable”.  Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by taking the average of these responses and re-coding them to range from 0 to 100.

Intermediate outcomes/Manipulation check

We theorize that the mechanism by which our treatments reduce out-group bias and threat is through inducing a sense of similarity with members of the out-group.  We will conduct two types of manipulation checks:  a series of questions following the experiments, and a qualitative analysis of the textual answers.

Index of question responses

Common Humanity condition: Creating a superordinate identity such as the human identity helps to recategorize out-group members, such that the out-group is now perceived as in-group members of a new superordinate identity category. This  mechanism can reduce bias and increase positive intergroup relations. As Gaertner and Dovidio (2005: 625) note, “if members of different groups are induced to conceive of themselves as a single group rather than as two completely separate groups, attitudes toward former outgroup members will become more positive through the cognitive and motivational forces that result from ingroup formation.”  Even more specifically, priming compassion, or helping behavior, can raise the superordinate identity to the level of common humanity and remind us that suffering is a shared human experience.  Compassion motivates helping behavior to alleviate another’s suffering, to forgive, and reduce punishment (DeSteno, Condon, and Dickens, Leah, 2016).  In our experiment, reading about the suffering of an out-group member because of a child’s grave illness reminds us of our shared humanity.
	
Our manipulation checks thus seek to identify whether respondents prioritize the human category over the partisan identity category.  We create an additive index from the following questions using a 5-point response scale:
The political party a person identifies with is less important than the fact that they are a human being, just as I am.
At the end of the day most Democrats and Republicans are good people who just want the best for their families.
I have little in common with people who disagree with me on politics.

Perspective-taking is the process of seeing the world from another’s vantage point; that is, putting oneself in another’s shoes.’ (Galinsky, Ku and Wang 2005). P-30.  Finding similarities with the out-group member  produces empathy and in turn reduces bias and stereotypes of the out-group member, while increasing positive evaluations.  This can happen at both the individual and group levels (Galinsky and Moskowitz, 2000). People who empathize more with the stigmatized group show a more positive attitude towards that group (Pettigrew and Tropp, 2008).  Thus our manipulation checks seek to identify whether people can imagine valid reasons for holding political views antithetical to one’s own, or for changing one’s political views.

People can have worthy reasons to change their political views.
I find it easy to accept that good people might have opposing political viewpoints to mine.
I find it hard to understand the rationales of Republicans/Democrats on most issues.
See above

Our estimands are sample average treatment effects (SATE) which we estimate through regressions predicting a set of composite dependent measures with two indicators for the two experimental groups relative to the control groups. We estimate linear regressions that predict our outcome of interest with indicators for treatment groups assignment as well as an additive index that we generate from questions measuring partisan identity strength. 

We estimate the same specification for mediators variables/intermediate outcomes as well. For robustness checks we also report a bivariate specification without this covariate for each model.

q22.value:
We give an attention check to terminate respondents indicative of fraudulent responses. First, they respond to a “trick question” proposed by Berinsky et al (2014). Then, we ask them to respond to a simple open ended question about a movie they had watched recently. We do so in order to screen out respondents unwilling or unable to engage with the essay writing stimuli which are our experimental interventions. Finally, because our hypotheses pertain to individuals with some attachment to either the Democrat or Republican party we terminate the survey for individuals who identify as pure independents. 

Thus, our analysis sample will consist of survey takers that 

(1) Identify or lean Democrat or Republican as per our ANES type question
(2) Pass our screener questions.

q23.value: We force respondents to respond to each of our outcome measures to continue with the survey.

q24.value: We estimate two kinds of heterogeneous treatment effects. First, we estimate these regressions separately for Democrats and Republicans. Second, we also explore whether baseline partisan identity strength moderates possible treatment effects. We do so by estimating treatment effects for 3 terciles of our continuous index of partisan identity strength. Finally, we also estimate effects separately for outcomes measuring attitudes towards elites and the mass public.

Each of these targets are rated on a 100-point scale with values not shown but choices labeled with “Extremely negative”, “Neither positive nor negative” and “Extremely positive”.

For our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between pairs of responses (e.g. |Republican voters - Democrat voters|), (2) averaging these absolute differences across pairs and (3) re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.
Traits

We next measure stereotypes that respondents might have about the voters of the two parties.  In particular, we ask “For each item, please indicate how well you think it applies to people who vote for the Democratic Party/Republican Party” and present subject with a matrix in which they rate the two targets on the following traits:
Patriotic
Intelligent
Open minded
Hypocritical
Selfish
Mean

For each trait, we provide 5 response options that range from “Not well at all” to “Extremely well”. We present each subject with this series of items for both parties in randomized order.

Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between pairs of responses (e.g. |Republicans are mean- Democrats are mean|), (2) averaging these absolute differences across pairs and (3) re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.

Emotions

We next measure the extent to which voters of the two parties trigger different emotions form subjects. In particular, we ask “To what extent do Democratic/Republican voters make you feel...” (
Disgusted
Angry
Afraid
Hopeful
Enthusiastic
Proud

For each trait, we provide 5 response options that range from “Not at all” to “A great deal”. We present each subject with this series of items for both parties in randomized order.

Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between pairs of responses (e.g. |Republicans are mean- Democrats are mean|), (2) averaging these absolute differences across pairs and (3) re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.

Trust

We next measure the extent to which subjects trust voters of the two parties. In particular, we ask “To what extent do you think you can trust Republican/Democratic Party voters to do what is right for the country?” 

We provide 5 response options that range from “Not at all” to “To a great deal.  Again, we ask about both parties in randomized order). 

Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by (1) taking the absolute difference between the two responses and re-coding these means to range from 0 to 100.

Social distance

Finally, we ask a series of 5 questions measuring social distance form the outparty. The questions are as follows:

How comfortable would you feel dating someone from a different political perspective (if you were single)?
How comfortable are you doing business with a supporter of the Democrats/Republicans?
Suppose a son or daughter of yours was getting married. How would you feel if he or she married a supporter of the Democrats/Republicans?
How comfortable are you having neighbors on your street who are Democrats/Republicans?
How comfortable are you having close personal friends who are Democrats/Republicans? 

For each item, we provide 5 response options that range from “Extremely comfortable” to “Extremely uncomfortable”.  Again, for our statistical analysis we recode these measures by taking the average of these responses and re-coding them to range from 0 to 100.

Intermediate outcomes/Manipulation check

We theorize that the mechanism by which our treatments reduce out-group bias and threat is through inducing a sense of similarity with members of the out-group.  We will conduct two types of manipulation checks:  a series of questions following the experiments, and a qualitative analysis of the textual answers.

Index of question responses

Common Humanity condition: Creating a superordinate identity such as the human identity helps to recategorize out-group members, such that the out-group is now perceived as in-group members of a new superordinate identity category. This  mechanism can reduce bias and increase positive intergroup relations. As Gaertner and Dovidio (2005: 625) note, “if members of different groups are induced to conceive of themselves as a single group rather than as two completely separate groups, attitudes toward former outgroup members will become more positive through the cognitive and motivational forces that result from ingroup formation.”  Even more specifically, priming compassion, or helping behavior, can raise the superordinate identity to the level of common humanity and remind us that suffering is a shared human experience.  Compassion motivates helping behavior to alleviate another’s suffering, to forgive, and reduce punishment (DeSteno, Condon, and Dickens, Leah, 2016).  In our experiment, reading about the suffering of an out-group member because of a child’s grave illness reminds us of our shared humanity.
	
Our manipulation checks thus seek to identify whether respondents prioritize the human category over the partisan identity category.  We create an additive index from the following questions using a 5-point response scale:
The political party a person identifies with is less important than the fact that they are a human being, just as I am.
At the end of the day most Democrats and Republicans are good people who just want the best for their families.
I have little in common with people who disagree with me on politics.

Perspective-taking is the process of seeing the world from another’s vantage point; that is, putting oneself in another’s shoes.’ (Galinsky, Ku and Wang 2005). P-30.  Finding similarities with the out-group member  produces empathy and in turn reduces bias and stereotypes of the out-group member, while increasing positive evaluations.  This can happen at both the individual and group levels (Galinsky and Moskowitz, 2000). People who empathize more with the stigmatized group show a more positive attitude towards that group (Pettigrew and Tropp, 2008).  Thus our manipulation checks seek to identify whether people can imagine valid reasons for holding political views antithetical to one’s own, or for changing one’s political views.

People can have worthy reasons to change their political views.
I find it easy to accept that good people might have opposing political viewpoints to mine.
I find it hard to understand the rationales of Republicans/Democrats on most issues.
registration_responses.q18.question: See above
registration_responses.q19.question:
Our estimands are sample average treatment effects (SATE) which we estimate through regressions predicting a set of composite dependent measures with two indicators for the two experimental groups relative to the control groups. We estimate linear regressions that predict our outcome of interest with indicators for treatment groups assignment as well as an additive index that we generate from questions measuring partisan identity strength. 

We estimate the same specification for mediators variables/intermediate outcomes as well. For robustness checks we also report a bivariate specification without this covariate for each model.

attributes.title: Predicting Implicit and Explicit Exercise Identity from Descriptive Social Norms

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Predicting Implicit and Explicit Exercise Identity from Descriptive Social Norms

sample.value: A power analysis was conducted to determine whether the number of participants in the AIID study (https://osf.io/pcjwf/; i.e., N = 500) would be sufficient to detect an incremental difference in R2 (power = .90, α = .05). Since the relation between descriptive norms and implicit identity has yet to be tested in the literature we estimated power using a small effect size (f2 = .03) with two tested predictors (i.e., proximal and distal descriptive norms) to be conservative. Results revealed that at least N = 425 participants would be needed to test our hypotheses. The AIID dataset had 500 participants relevant to this study, thus we are sufficiently powered to answer our research questions.

analyses.value:
Two multiple regression analyses will be conducted to test the primary hypothesis with the predictor variables being proximal and distal social norms and the outcome variable being either implicit or explicit exercise identity. 

For our non-directional exploratory hypothesis, two Fischer's Z tests will be conducted. The first will compare whether proximal social norms is a stronger predictor of implicit or explicit exercise identity. The second will compare whether distal social norms is a stronger predictor of implicit or explicit exercise identity.

outliers.value:
Participants were only included if they were assigned to complete the implicit measure of exercise self-identity and associated self-report measures in either of their research sessions (see https://osf.io/pcjwf/ for full research procedure of the Attitudes, Identities, and Individual Differences Study).

Additionally, we will detect multivariate outliers using Mahalanobis distance values (p < .001; critical value χ2 = 16.27). These will be conducted for the pairing of either implicit or explicit exercise identity with proximal and descriptive social norms. Multivariate outliers will be removed and the analysis will be re-conducted until there are no outliers remaining at the specified critical value. The tests of hypotheses will be conducted both with and without the inclusion of multivariate outliers and will be reported both ways if these results differ. If results do not differ, then results will only be reported with the inclusion of multivariate outliers to demonstrate robustness of results.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variables are explicit and implicit exercise identity (see https://osf.io/pcjwf/ for full variable list). 

Explicit exercise identity was measured in using a single-item from the AIID Study: ‘How much is exercise part of your self-concept?’ (Hussey et al., 2018). Response options were rated on a 6-point Likert-type scale ranging from: 1 = ‘None at all’ to 6 = ‘Very Much’. 

Implicit exercise identity was measured using the exercise identity IAT stimuli from the categories exercising (i.e., ‘Lift Weights’, ‘Run’, ‘Jump’, ‘Workout’, Aerobics’, and ‘Crosstraining’), relaxing (i.e., ‘Sit’, ‘Rest’, ‘Watch TV’, ‘Snooze’, ‘Recline’, and ‘Lie Down’) and stimuli from the attributes self (i.e., ‘I’, ‘Me’, ‘Mine’, ‘Myself’, and ‘Self’), and other (i.e.,’ Other’, ‘They’, ‘Them’, ‘Their’, and ‘Theirs’)  (Hussey et al., 2018). Greenwald and colleagues (2003) scoring algorithm will be used to score the IAT.

conditions.value: This study is observational in nature and thus participants were not assigned to a condition (https://osf.io/pcjwf/)

hypothesis.value: The main hypothesis is that proximal (i.e., close others) and distal descriptive (i.e., the average person) social norms that are more supportive of exercise will predict stronger implicit and explicit exercise identities. The study also examines whether proximal and distal descriptive social norms will more strongly predict implicit or explicit exerciser identities. This hypothesis is non-directional.

study_type_other.value: We are utilizing data from the Attitudes, Identities, and Individual Differences Study (https://osf.io/pcjwf/). We answered a call for Registered Reports and have had our Stage 1 registered reported accepted at Psychology and Health. Both the initial Stage 1 acceptance and this pre-registration were completed before we were given access to the full confirmatory dataset.
