data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: A two-way ANOVA will be conducted to test whether there are differences in consumer satisfaction by condition. We will also test whether individual differences in tipping attitude moderates any effects.

sample.value: We calculated the sample size using G*Power for an a priori power analysis, which estimated a total sample size of 128 to reach a power of .80 at p = .05. To account for participants that do not meet the inclusion criteria or encounter computer malfunction, we set a target sample size of 150.

analyses.value:
A two-way ANOVA using will be conducted to determine whether there are differences in tip amount, by the service type and tip format conditions.  Tip amount will be calculated by the absolute value of participants’ selection (e.g., if they select “no tip”, this will be coded as “0” in analyses). 

To determine whether obligations to tip and social norms play a causal role in tip amount, we will test for mediation.

outliers.value: Exclusions: Participant data will be excluded from analyses if they provide nonsensical data.

dependent.value: Participants will read a scenario for either a high or low service encounter. Following, participants will be asked how much of a tip they want to leave on this service. We will manipulate the tip format of this question to either include suggested tip amount, or no suggestion.

conditions.value: The study will utilize a 2 (Service type: high, low) X 2 (Tip format: suggested, not suggested) between-subjects design.

hypothesis.value: The goal of this experiment is to examine how suggested tip amounts influence tipping in high and low service encounters. In our pre-test, results indicated that individuals tipped more if a service was considered high effort, compared to when it was considered low effort, t(144) = 6.46, p < .001, d = 1.07. For this study, we aim to see whether adding suggested tips (default options) will make individuals tip more for low service encounters, and whether this can be explained by perceived changes in social norms, and/or increased obligation to tip. We will also see whether adding suggested tip options influences consumer satisfaction.

attributes.title: Life stress on secure base script knowledge

q1.value: Reversibility or predicate properties? Word order variability in silent gesture

q2.value: Marieke Schouwstra, Simon Kirby, Danielle Naegeli

q3.value:
Silent gesture experiments have uncovered word order preferences that are (at least in part) independent of the native language of participants, which have been used to draw conclusions about how people structure information in the absence of an existing system of linguistic conventions. For instance, Goldin-Meadow et al. (2008) observed a preference for SOV for extensional, non-reversible events (like ‘girl covers box’). They called this word order ‘natural’ and emphasised the key role of SOV order in language evolution. 

More recent experimental work, however, showed that in silent gesture, participants use different word orders depending on the semantic properties of the event they convey information about. In a number of publications, a preference for SVO (alongside other orders, like OSV) was found for reversible events, in which the patient is animate, like in ‘girl pushes boy’ (Meir et al., 2010; Hall et al., 2014; Gibson et al., 2013). 

Silent gesture experiments provide a context where participants are robbed of existing linguistic conventions, and improvise to convey information in a novel way. The word order alternations that arise under these circumstances can help us uncover basic strategies people adhere to when engaged in communication. However, it is important to understand exactly why these word order patterns arise. In the case of the SOV/SVO alternation for reversibility, we need to know what is crucial about reversibility of an action.   

Reversibility of an action is often defined as directly related to the participants of that action: reversible actions typically have two animate participants. We aim to investigate a more detailed breakdown of the reversible/non-reversible distinction, by proposing that non-reversible events come in two flavours. Some transitive actions (e.g. ‘push’ or ‘stroke’) are non-reversible when the patient is inanimate, but can be made reversible by making the patient animate. However, not all actions are suitable for having two animate participants; for example, if an action like ‘eat’ or ‘crumple’ is combined with an animate patient, the resulting event becomes conceptually or physically highly unlikely. This suggests that patient-animacy is not the only important factor in reversibility, but also the properties of the action, and the constraints it places on the properties of its participants.

We will compare events of the two proposed sub-categories: non-reversible events in the broad sense (e.g. ‘a woman pushes a box’), and in the strict sense (e.g. ‘a woman eats an apple’). The former is eligible for becoming reversible when the two participants are animate, and the latter is not likely to occur as a reversible event.

In a previous study (see preregistration at https://osf.io/unw98 ) in which pairs of participants took turns to communicate about non-reversible and reversible events, we tested the same distinction, and found relatively high proportions of SVO overall, and SOV proportions to be higher in the strict-non-reversible trials, than in both the broad-non-reversible and the reversible trials. In this study, the broad-non-reversible trials were more similar to the reversible trials than the strict-non-reversible trials, i.e., broad-non-reversibles and reversible occurred with the same actions and the same agents, whereas strict-non-reversibles had entirely different agents and actions.

In the current study, we will make sure that the three kinds of events all have different actions, agents and patients. This will guarantee that the three classes are equally dissimilar, and if we still find a difference between the two non-reversible events, we can be sure it is due to the affordances of the action alone. 

Additionally, in silent gesture experiments that test non-reversible events alone, very high levels of SOV are observed (Goldin-Meadow et al., 2008), whereas overall levels of SOV (even for non-reversible events) are lower in general when non-reversible events are presented alongside reversible events (Hall et al., 2013; Gibson et al., 2013). Hall et al. (2013) investigated the influence of of reversible events on the proportion of SOV for non-reversible events, by testing three conditions: in the first condition, participants first described non-reversible events (of the two kinds described above), and subsequently reversible events. In the second condition, participants saw reversible events first, and subsequently non-reversible events. In the third, reversible and non-reversibles were mixed. Surprisingly, no influence of the position of reversible was found on the proportion of SOV for non-reversibles. This result is in contradiction to our previous study (see brief description above, and preregistration https://osf.io/unw98), in which really high proportions of SVO---and low proportions of SOV---are observed throughout.  

By creating two conditions, in which the order of presentation of reversible vs non-reversible differs, we aim to find out whether the presence of reversible events influences the word order of subsequent non-reversible trials.

q4.value:
(1)	If the properties of the action (and the constraints these properties place on the participants of the action) have additional explanatory power, on top of patient-animacy, in determining word order variability in silent gesture, we should see a difference between the two event types, strictly-non-reversible events and broadly-defined-non-reversible-events, in the sense that the former behave less like reversible events than the latter. We should see this reflected in a higher proportion of SOV for strictly non-reversible events than for broadly defined non-reversible events.
(2)	If a difference between the two types of non-reversible events is expressed in word order, we expect this difference to become less prominent over repeated productions through a process of regularisation (Ferdinand et al., 2019).  
(3)	If producing a high proportion of SVO gesture strings in silent gesture influences gesture production in later trials, we should expect lower overall proportions of SOV for non-reversible events when participants describe reversible events first than when they describe reversible events after the non-reversible events.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experiment consists of two phases. In the reversible-first condition, participants will see  reversible events first, followed by broad-non-reversibles and strict-non-reversibles (the latter two will be mixed). In the reversible-last condition, participants will see reversible events after the non-reversible events (again, the two types of non-reversibles will be mixed). 

Participants take part in the experiment alone. Stimuli are presented one by one, in random order, with the following restrictions:
-	In the non-reversible phase, we will alternate the two kinds of non-reversible events. 
-	We will counterbalance the type of the first item in the non-reversible phase (for half of the participants this will come from the broad-non-reversible class, and for the other half this will come from the strict-non-reversibles.
-	In both phases of the experiment, we will make sure that every two consecutive trials will not share any elements (agent, patient, or action). 

In each trial, the participant is asked to produce gestures to convey what they see to the experimenter. 

To familiarise participants with the task, prior to the actual experiment, participants will see two practice items (from the category/ies they see first, but using actor/patient/actions that do not occur at all in the actual experiment). For each practice item, the experimenter will ask the participant to provide gestures to convey what they see. In this stage, whenever a participant omits any of the three relevant elements (agent, patient and action) the experimenter will prompt the participant to convey more information, but will avoid using any words to refer to the individual elements (agent, patient, action) in the event. 

After the practice items, the actual experiment starts, and in this stage, participants do not receive feedback. 

After running through the items and producing gestures for each trial, participants will be asked to describe each item in one sentence, in written English. We will use these to check if participants understood the action intended in each line drawing (see analysis).

See https://osf.io/2pr48/ for all stimulus materials.

q9.value:
We will use two conditions, which have the same stimuli sets, but stimuli are presented in different orders across two phases (see details above). 

Participants will be assigned to a condition based on a random number list generated in python.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be right handed native speakers of English, recruited from the University of Edinburgh career platform. Participants will be paid £5 for a 30min experiment.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 participants in 2 conditions (20 participants per condition).

question.value:
We will record the word orders used on each trial to describe an event, and assign it to one of two categories: SOV vs other. 

In addition, to be able to compare our results to existing results (e.g. Hall et al., 2013), we will do finer grained coding too, determining the word order for each string. We will use the written English responses to check if participants understood each item in the way in which we intended it, and remove those trials that were interpreted as being from a different event class. The coding procedure will be the same as that in Schouwstra et al (in prep). 

Further, we will code for the presence of “marking” for agenthood and patienthood. 

Finally, we will assess how participants interpreted the line drawings by asking them to describe each drawing in spoken English and determining whether each predicate was interpreted as belonging to the right category (strict-non-reversible, broad-non-reversible, or reversible).

To find out if non-reversible events in the strict sense behave differently from non-reversible events in the broad sense, we will focus on the non-reversible trials in the reversible-last condition, and compare SOV strings for strict-non-reversibles and broad-non-reversibles respectively, in a binomial mixed effects regression that models SOV, taking non-reversible-type (either strict or broad) as fixed effect, random intercepts and slopes for non-rev-type on participant and random intercepts on items. 

To check if this difference is regularised over trials, we run an additional model taking the same model as above but adding trial number as a fixed effect, plus the interaction between non-reversible-type and trial number.

To find out if the order of presentation matters for the proportion of SOV used in non-reversible events, we compare those levels in the two conditions, using a a binomial mixed effects regression that models SOV, taking condition as a fixed effect, and random intercepts for participant and random slopes on condition for item.

q24.value:
We will look at marking of agenthood and patienthood. Our first aim is to see if we replicate the finding by Hall et al., 2013, that marking is more frequent for reversible than for non-reversible events. Secondly, we will look at the reversible-first condition: Hall et al. (2013) found that when participants saw reversible events first, they were more likely to use marking on non-reversibles too. We will investigate a more detailed prediction concerning the two types of non-reversibles; we expect (in the reversible first condition) broad-non-reversible events to be more likely to have marking than strict-non-reversible events. 
The reason this prediction is in this section rather than in the hypothesis section is that we are not sure about the plans for coding for the marking. Hall et al. (2013) report cases of lexical marking (participants using gestures like '1' or '2' to mark the difference between the roles), but  we expect to be looking at body shift in addition to this.

q25.value:

   Goldin-Meadow, S., So, W. C., Özyürek, A., & Mylander, C. (2008). The natural order of events: How speakers of different languages represent events nonverbally. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 105(27), 9163-9168.

In a number of publications, a preference for SVO (alongside other orders, like OSV) was found for reversible events, in which the patient is animate, like in ‘girl pushes boy’ (Meir et al., 2010; Hall et al., 2014; Gibson et al., 2013). 

Silent gesture experiments provide a context where participants are robbed of existing linguistic conventions, and improvise to convey information in a novel way. The word order alternations that arise under these circumstances can help us uncover basic strategies people adhere to when engaged in communication. However, it is important to understand exactly why these word order patterns arise. In the case of the SOV/SVO alternation for reversibility, we need to know what is crucial about reversibility of an action.   

Reversibility of an action is often defined as directly related to the participants of that action: reversible actions typically have two animate participants. We aim to investigate a more detailed breakdown of the reversible/non-reversible distinction, by proposing that non-reversible events come in two flavours. Some transitive actions (e.g. ‘push’ or ‘stroke’) are non-reversible when the patient is inanimate, but can be made reversible by making the patient animate. However, not all actions are suitable for having two animate participants; for example, if an action like ‘eat’ or ‘crumple’ is combined with an animate patient, the resulting event becomes conceptually or physically highly unlikely. This suggests that patient-animacy is not the only important factor in reversibility, but also the properties of the action, and the constraints it places on the properties of its participants.

We will compare events of the two proposed sub-categories: non-reversible events in the broad sense (e.g. ‘a woman pushes a box’), and in the strict sense (e.g. ‘a woman eats an apple’). The former is eligible for becoming reversible when the two participants are animate, and the latter is not likely to occur as a reversible event.

In a previous study (see preregistration at https://osf.io/unw98 ) in which pairs of participants took turns to communicate about non-reversible and reversible events, we tested the same distinction, and found relatively high proportions of SVO overall, and SOV proportions to be higher in the strict-non-reversible trials, than in both the broad-non-reversible and the reversible trials. In this study, the broad-non-reversible trials were more similar to the reversible trials than the strict-non-reversible trials, i.e., broad-non-reversibles and reversible occurred with the same actions and the same agents, whereas strict-non-reversibles had entirely different agents and actions.

In the current study, we will make sure that the three kinds of events all have different actions, agents and patients. This will guarantee that the three classes are equally dissimilar, and if we still find a difference between the two non-reversible events, we can be sure it is due to the affordances of the action alone. 

Additionally, in silent gesture experiments that test non-reversible events alone, very high levels of SOV are observed (Goldin-Meadow et al., 2008), whereas overall levels of SOV (even for non-reversible events) are lower in general when non-reversible events are presented alongside reversible events (Hall et al., 2013; Gibson et al., 2013). Hall et al. (2013) investigated the influence of of reversible events on the proportion of SOV for non-reversible events, by testing three conditions: in the first condition, participants first described non-reversible events (of the two kinds described above), and subsequently reversible events. In the second condition, participants saw reversible events first, and subsequently non-reversible events. In the third, reversible and non-reversibles were mixed. Surprisingly, no influence of the position of reversible was found on the proportion of SOV for non-reversibles. This result is in contradiction to our previous study (see brief description above, and preregistration https://osf.io/unw98), in which really high proportions of SVO---and low proportions of SOV---are observed throughout.  

By creating two conditions, in which the order of presentation of reversible vs non-reversible differs, we aim to find out whether the presence of reversible events influences the word order of subsequent non-reversible trials.
registration_responses.q4:
(1)	If the properties of the action (and the constraints these properties place on the participants of the action) have additional explanatory power, on top of patient-animacy, in determining word order variability in silent gesture, we should see a difference between the two event types, strictly-non-reversible events and broadly-defined-non-reversible-events, in the sense that the former behave less like reversible events than the latter. We should see this reflected in a higher proportion of SOV for strictly non-reversible events than for broadly defined non-reversible events.
(2)	If a difference between the two types of non-reversible events is expressed in word order, we expect this difference to become less prominent over repeated productions through a process of regularisation (Ferdinand et al., 2019).  
(3)	If producing a high proportion of SVO gesture strings in silent gesture influences gesture production in later trials, we should expect lower overall proportions of SOV for non-reversible events when participants describe reversible events first than when they describe reversible events after the non-reversible events.

registration_responses.q24:
We will look at marking of agenthood and patienthood. Our first aim is to see if we replicate the finding by Hall et al., 2013, that marking is more frequent for reversible than for non-reversible events. Secondly, we will look at the reversible-first condition: Hall et al. (2013) found that when participants saw reversible events first, they were more likely to use marking on non-reversibles too. We will investigate a more detailed prediction concerning the two types of non-reversibles; we expect (in the reversible first condition) broad-non-reversible events to be more likely to have marking than strict-non-reversible events. 
The reason this prediction is in this section rather than in the hypothesis section is that we are not sure about the plans for coding for the marking. Hall et al. (2013) report cases of lexical marking (participants using gestures like '1' or '2' to mark the difference between the roles), but  we expect to be looking at body shift in addition to this.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The experiment consists of two phases. In the reversible-first condition, participants will see  reversible events first, followed by broad-non-reversibles and strict-non-reversibles (the latter two will be mixed). In the reversible-last condition, participants will see reversible events after the non-reversible events (again, the two types of non-reversibles will be mixed). 

Participants take part in the experiment alone. Stimuli are presented one by one, in random order, with the following restrictions:
-	In the non-reversible phase, we will alternate the two kinds of non-reversible events. 
-	We will counterbalance the type of the first item in the non-reversible phase (for half of the participants this will come from the broad-non-reversible class, and for the other half this will come from the strict-non-reversibles.
-	In both phases of the experiment, we will make sure that every two consecutive trials will not share any elements (agent, patient, or action). 

In each trial, the participant is asked to produce gestures to convey what they see to the experimenter. 

To familiarise participants with the task, prior to the actual experiment, participants will see two practice items (from the category/ies they see first, but using actor/patient/actions that do not occur at all in the actual experiment). For each practice item, the experimenter will ask the participant to provide gestures to convey what they see. In this stage, whenever a participant omits any of the three relevant elements (agent, patient and action) the experimenter will prompt the participant to convey more information, but will avoid using any words to refer to the individual elements (agent, patient, action) in the event. 

After the practice items, the actual experiment starts, and in this stage, participants do not receive feedback. 

After running through the items and producing gestures for each trial, participants will be asked to describe each item in one sentence, in written English. We will use these to check if participants understood the action intended in each line drawing (see analysis).

See https://osf.io/2pr48/ for all stimulus materials.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be right handed native speakers of English, recruited from the University of Edinburgh career platform. Participants will be paid £5 for a 30min experiment.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will record the word orders used on each trial to describe an event, and assign it to one of two categories: SOV vs other. 

In addition, to be able to compare our results to existing results (e.g. Hall et al., 2013), we will do finer grained coding too, determining the word order for each string. We will use the written English responses to check if participants understood each item in the way in which we intended it, and remove those trials that were interpreted as being from a different event class. The coding procedure will be the same as that in Schouwstra et al (in prep). 

Further, we will code for the presence of “marking” for agenthood and patienthood. 

Finally, we will assess how participants interpreted the line drawings by asking them to describe each drawing in spoken English and determining whether each predicate was interpreted as belonging to the right category (strict-non-reversible, broad-non-reversible, or reversible).
registration_responses.q19.question:
To find out if non-reversible events in the strict sense behave differently from non-reversible events in the broad sense, we will focus on the non-reversible trials in the reversible-last condition, and compare SOV strings for strict-non-reversibles and broad-non-reversibles respectively, in a binomial mixed effects regression that models SOV, taking non-reversible-type (either strict or broad) as fixed effect, random intercepts and slopes for non-rev-type on participant and random intercepts on items. 

To check if this difference is regularised over trials, we run an additional model taking the same model as above but adding trial number as a fixed effect, plus the interaction between non-reversible-type and trial number.

To find out if the order of presentation matters for the proportion of SOV used in non-reversible events, we compare those levels in the two conditions, using a a binomial mixed effects regression that models SOV, taking condition as a fixed effect, and random intercepts for participant and random slopes on condition for item.
